headline.print_headline: Some Guys Have It All, but Not in This Species
headline.main: Seductive Bass Tones Enough to Seal the Deal in Some Monkey Species

snippet: A study of howler monkeys finds that to gain a mating advantage, species evolved either to make very low frequency sounds, or have much larger testicles, but none had both.
abstract: Scientists researching primate reproduction publish study in journal Current Biology reporting some species of howler monkeys have deep voices but small testicles, while other species have the reverse; evolutionary trade-off is possibly explained by differences in regional lifestyles, physical energy required to develop both and momentum established once evolutionary path was taken.
lead_paragraph: A study of howler monkeys finds that to gain a mating advantage, species evolved either to make very low frequency sounds, or have much larger testicles, but none had both.
